data.title: AMS :: 1997 Joint Mathematics Meetings, Invited Addresses
data.text:
AMS Meeting Invited Addresses

Current as of Tuesday, April 12, 2005 15:09:38

Program | Deadlines | Inquiries: meet@ams.org

1997 Joint Mathematics Meetings

San Diego, CA, January 8-11, 1997

Meeting #918

Associate secretaries:

Lesley M Sibner, AMS lsibner@duke.poly.edu

Donovan H Van Osdol, MAA dv@christa.unh.edu

Invited Addresses

Miklos Ajtai, IBM Almaden Research Center, Induction, counting and approximate counting in finite structures (ASL)

Jeremy Avigad, Carnegie Mellon University, The combinatorics of propositional provability (ASL)

Charles Bell, San Diego State University, Some of My Favorite Mathematicans (NAM)

Edward Bierstone, University of Toronto, Resolution of singularities.

Gregory Cherlin, Rutgers University, Tame groups and finite simple groups (ASL)

Persi Diaconis, Harvard University, Patterns in Eigenvalues

Solomon Feferman, Stanford University, Does mathematics need new axioms?

Michael H. Freedman, University of California, San Diego, The notion of limit in topology, geometry, and algorithmic complexity

Guershon Harel, Purdue University,West Lafayette, A fundamental principle of learning and its application in modifying students' conceptions of mathematical proof

Morris W. Hirsch, University of California, Berkeley, Myth, meaning and metaphor in mathematics.

Carlos Imaz, CINVESTAV del IPN, What is wrong with calculus?

Russell Impagliazzo, University of California, San Diego, The Groebner basis algorithm and propositional proof systems (ASL)

Jorge Ize, IIMAS-UNAM, Equivariant degree

Dan Kalman, The Mathematical Association of America, Automatic Differentiation: Computing Derivative Values without Derivative Formulas

James Kaput, University of Massachussetts, Dartmouth, The deepening impact of technology on mathematics and the means by which it can be learned and taught: The case of mathematics of change and variation

Nancy Kopell, Department of Mathematics, Boston University, Networks of Neurons and Dynamical Systems

Harold W. Kuhn, Princeton University, A half century of game theory

Claude Laflamme, University of Calgary, Gaps: Some structure and some applications (ASL)

Neal F. Lane, National Science Foundation, Problem solving in complex societies.

Carolyn R. Mahoney, California State University, San Marcos/MSRI, Independent Partitons and Independent Set Numbers of Matroids (NAM)

Daniel Mauldin, University of North Texas, Some topics on the interface between set theory and analysis (ASL)

Monica McArthur, University of California, Los Angeles, Nonconvergence for sparse random graphs (ASL)

Cathleen Morawetz, Courant Institute-New York University, Mathematics to the rescue: Some personal recollections.

Linda P. Rothschild, UCSD, How do real manifolds live in complex space? (AWM)

Edward F. Schaefer, Santa Clara University, When is an integer the product of two and three consecutive integers?

Christine Shoemaker, Cornell University, Applications of Optimization, Numerical Analysis, and High Performance Computing to Environmental Restoration of Groundwater

Mikhail A. Shubin, Northeastern University, Von Neumann algebra techniques in analysis and topology.

Mary Silber, Northwestern University, Dynamics, Symmetry and Pattern-forming Instabilities in Physical Systems

Patrick Speissegger, Fields Institute, The field of reals with the Gamma function is o-minimal (ASL)

Daniel W. Stroock, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Analysis on spaces of paths

Daniel W. Stroock, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Analysis on spaces of paths

Daniel W. Stroock, Massachusetts Institute of Technnology, Analysis on spaces of paths.

William T. Trotter,, Partially Ordered Sets
